conclusion: We need to determine the speed of the block when it slides from point A to point B and the ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B.
The block is released from rest at point A and slides down the circular track to point B.

The fixed smooth circular track ACB has a radius of 0.8m. Point A is on the same horizontal line as the center O, and the bottom point B of the circular track is on the same vertical line as the center. Point C is 0.2m vertically above point B.
The height difference between A and B is the radius of the circle, which is 0.8m.
The potential energy at A is converted to kinetic energy at B.
The potential energy at A is PE_A = mgh_A = mg * 0.8m.
The kinetic energy at B is KE_B = (1/2)mv_B^2.
By conservation of energy, PE_A = KE_B.
Substituting values, mg * 0.8m = (1/2)mv_B^2.
Solving for v_B, v_B = sqrt(2g * 0.8m).
Substituting g = 10m/s^2, v_B = sqrt(2 * 10 * 0.8) = sqrt(16) = 4m/s.
The speed of the block when it slides from point A to point B is 4m/s.
At point B, the block is moving horizontally with speed 4m/s.
The normal force F_N and the gravitational force mg act on the block.
Since there is no vertical acceleration, the net force in the vertical direction is zero.
Using Newton's second law in the vertical direction, F_N - mg = 0.
Solving for F_N, F_N = mg.
The ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B is F_N/mg = mg/mg = 1.
The ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B is 1.
The final answers are: Speed of the block when it slides from point A to point B = 4m/s, and Ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B = 1.
